verses.text: Save me, O God, for the waters have come up to my neck.
verses.comment: The image of overwhelming waters often symbolizes affliction, distress, or even judgment. This opening plea sets a tone of utter desperation.

verses.text: I sink in deep mire, where there is no foothold; I have come into deep waters, and the flood sweeps over me.
verses.comment: The 'deep mire' and 'flood' intensify the feeling of helplessness. Spiritually, this captures the human experience of being overwhelmed by sin or suffering.

verses.text: I am weary with my crying out; my throat is parched. My eyes fail while I wait for my God.
verses.comment: 'Waiting for God' implies persistent faith through trial. The exhaustion mirrors Christ's suffering (cf. Ps. 22:15, fulfilled in John 19:28).

verses.text: More numerous than the hairs of my head are those who hate me without reason; many are those who want to destroy me, my enemies without cause. What I did not steal, I must repay.
verses.comment: This verse is cited of Christ (John 15:25), emphasizing the theme of unjust hatred. The innocent sufferer motif points toward Jesus' passion.

verses.text: O God, you know my foolishness, and my wrongs are not hidden from you.
verses.comment: Although innocent in the situation, the psalmist acknowledges human imperfection. This openness before God's gaze anticipates the call to confession and reconciliation.

verses.text: Let not those who wait for you be put to shame through me, O Lord GOD of hosts; let not those who seek you be dishonored because of me, O God of Israel.
verses.comment: The psalmist shows communal concern, aware of the effect his suffering may have on others. This intercessory spirit reflects a heart attuned to the unity and witness of God's people.

verses.text: For it is for your sake that I bear reproach, that shame has covered my face.
verses.comment: Suffering 'for your sake' foreshadows the concept of redemptive suffering, later fulfilled perfectly in Christ (see Rom. 15:3).

verses.text: I have become a stranger to my brothers, an alien to my mother's children.
verses.comment: This estrangement anticipates Jesus' rejection by His own family and hometown (Matt. 13:57).

verses.text: For zeal for your house has consumed me, and the insults of those who insult you have fallen on me.
verses.comment: Directly quoted in John 2:17, this verse is applied to Christ's cleansing of the Temple, showing the Psalm's prophetic reach. Christ’s identification with God's honor becomes a model for sacrificial service.

verses.text: When I wept and fasted, I was mocked for it.
verses.comment: Fasting and intercession lead not to praise but mockery—an inversion common in the path of the righteous. The faithful are called to persevere even when misunderstood.

verses.text: I made sackcloth my clothing, and I became a byword to them.
verses.comment: Sackcloth symbolizes repentance and mourning. Even righteous acts become occasions for scorn in a fallen world.

verses.text: I am the talk of those who sit at the city gate, and the drunkards make songs about me.
verses.comment: The city gate was a place where judgments were made; public ridicule here refers to widespread humiliation.

verses.text: But as for me, my prayer is to you, O LORD, at an acceptable time; O God, in your abundant love, answer me with your sure salvation.
verses.comment: 'Acceptable time' echoes the notion of God's chosen moment for deliverance (cf. Isa. 49:8), suggesting God acts according to His plan.

verses.text: Deliver me from the mire, and do not let me sink; let me be delivered from those who hate me, and out of the deep waters.
verses.comment: Repeats the imagery of verse 2, signifying a desperate appeal for rescue from both personal and communal enemies.

verses.text: Do not let the flood sweep over me, or the deep swallow me up, or the pit close its mouth over me.
verses.comment: References to the 'pit' connect death and Sheol, reinforcing a theme of deliverance from mortal danger.

verses.text: Answer me, O LORD, for your steadfast love is good; in your great mercy, turn to me.
verses.comment: The psalmist appeals to God's character—steadfast love and mercy—as grounds for hope.

verses.text: Do not hide your face from your servant, for I am in distress; swiftly answer me.
verses.comment: 'Hide your face' is a metaphor for divine absence; the psalmist earnestly seeks God's attentive presence.

verses.text: Draw near to my soul and redeem it; ransom me because of my enemies.
verses.comment: The prayer for ransom and closeness foreshadows the need for a Redeemer who acts personally for our deliverance.

verses.text: You know my reproach, my shame, and my dishonor; all my adversaries are before you.
verses.comment: The psalmist confides in God's perfect knowledge, a comfort amid suffering and slander.

verses.text: Insults have broken my heart, so I am in despair; I looked for pity, but there was none, and for comforters, but I found none.
verses.comment: This is echoed in the passion of Jesus, who suffered abandonment and mockery (see Mark 15:34).

verses.text: They gave me poison for food, and for my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink.
verses.comment: This prophetic detail is directly fulfilled at the crucifixion (Matt. 27:34, John 19:28-29), tying David’s suffering to the greater Innocent One.

verses.text: Let their table before them become a trap, and when they are at peace, let it become a snare.
verses.comment: Paul quotes this to describe Israel's hardening in Romans 11:9-10, an example of how blessings can become judgment if rejected.

verses.text: Let their eyes be darkened so they cannot see, and make their backs bend forever.
verses.comment: This continues the previous thought. Spiritual blindness and burdens are pictured here as consequences for persistent opposition to God.

verses.text: Pour out your indignation upon them, and let your burning anger overtake them.
verses.comment: These 'imprecatory' requests reflect a plea for justice, not personal vengeance. In the new covenant, the Lord transforms these cries into a longing for restoration and mercy.

verses.text: Let their camp be a desolation; let no one dwell in their tents.
verses.comment: Acts 1:20 applies this to Judas Iscariot, connecting the psalm to events in Christ’s passion and the early Church’s emergence.

verses.text: For they persecute him whom you have struck down, and they recount the pain of those you have wounded.
verses.comment: Those who add injury to the afflicted oppose not just the person but the plan of God, a reminder of the mystery of suffering.

verses.text: Add guilt to their guilt; let them not enter into your righteousness.
verses.comment: This hard word should be read in the context of biblical justice and the desire for the vindication of God's truth.

verses.text: Let them be blotted out of the book of the living; let them not be enrolled among the righteous.
verses.comment: Mention of the 'book of the living' prefigures later revelation about the Book of Life (see Rev. 3:5), suggesting the lasting consequences of one's choices.

verses.text: But I am afflicted and in pain; let your salvation, O God, set me on high.
verses.comment: Rising above affliction by God’s saving action is a theme realized most fully in the resurrection of Christ.

verses.text: I will praise the name of God with a song; I will magnify him with thanksgiving.
verses.comment: Despite suffering, the psalmist moves to praise, echoing the liturgical tradition of thanksgiving in the presence of the assembly.

verses.text: This will please the LORD more than an ox, or a bull with horns and hoofs.
verses.comment: Sacrificial praise and thanksgiving are more pleasing to God than ritual offerings, prefiguring the spiritual worship emphasized in the new covenant.

verses.text: The humble will see and rejoice; you who seek God, let your hearts live!
verses.comment: God’s salvation brings hope to the humble and encouragement to all seekers, a foreshadowing of the blessedness promised by Christ.

verses.text: For the LORD hears the needy and does not despise his own who are prisoners.
verses.comment: God’s heart for the afflicted is a constant Old Testament theme, and reaches fulfillment in Jesus’ ministry to the poor and imprisoned.

verses.text: Let heaven and earth praise him, the seas and everything that moves in them.
verses.comment: All creation is called to join in praise, reflecting the cosmic scope of God’s redemption.

verses.text: For God will save Zion and build up the cities of Judah, and people will live there and possess it.
verses.comment: The restoration of Zion has an immediate and a greater spiritual meaning, prefiguring the gathering and sanctification of God’s people.

verses.text: The descendants of his servants will inherit it, and those who love his name will dwell in it.
verses.comment: The inheritance language points to the ultimate promise of eternal dwelling with God for those who love Him. The unity between praise, worship, and God's faithful people is a persistent theme here.
